newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: No word on condition of Singapore's Lee Kuan Yew.
newsitem.headline: No word on condition of Singapore's Lee Kuan Yew.

text.p: Singapore hospital officials declined comment on Sunday on the condition of Lee Kuan Yew, the city-state's long-time former prime minister who entered hospital on Saturday for scheduled tests on his bladder.
Officials at Singapore General Hospital, where Lee was examined on Saturday by the head of the urology department, told Reuters they could give out no information on him.
Government officials were unavailable for comment.

The office of Prime Minister Goh Chok Tong issued a brief statement on Saturday saying that Lee, 73, had had chronic inflammatory tissue removed from the wall of his bladder on two previous occasions.
"His stay in hospital will depend upon the extent of the operation," it said. It gave no other details of his condition.
Lee, who led Singapore for 31 years until 1990 and remains in the cabinet as Senior Minister, retains considerable political influence.
He underwent two heart operations in early 1996, raising fears of a drop on local financial markets.
The markets took news of his condition in their stride, however, a reaction which Lee said afterwards proved Singapore had accepted that the reins of power had passed to a new generation.
A doctor contacted by Reuters on Saturday said inflammation of the bladder was a fairly common condition and was usually caused by an infection.
"The idea of the tests may be to make sure there's nothing more serious -- to make sure it is not cancerous," said the doctor, who declined to be identified.
